;;伦敦西北部温布利公园剧院外的拉塞尔·布兰德
;

;BBC 正在调查声称拉塞尔·布兰德 (Russell Brand) 在他的广播节目中大笑之前向一名女性展示了照片。

;

;据 BBC 新闻报道，该事件据称发生在 2008 年，当时该女性与该公司位于洛杉矶的办公室在同一栋大楼内工作。

;

;几分钟后，据说这位喜剧演员在他的联合主持人马特·摩根说布兰德“向一位女士展示了他的阴茎”时笑了。

;

;据报道，这名女士“惊呆了，

;

;BBC 发言人在一份声明中表示：“听到这些指控我们感到非常遗憾，我们将对此进行调查。

;

;“我们正在对此类性质的指控进行审查，如果分享其故事的妇女愿意与我们交谈，我们将非常渴望听到她和任何其他可能有信息的人的来信。

;

; “审查的一个关键部分是了解当时提出了哪些投诉，是否了解拉塞尔·布兰德在 BBC 电台工作期间的行为，以及因此采取的措施。

;

;“我们当然，作为其中的一部分，我们将与局团队以及 2008 年在那里工作的任何人进行交谈。

;

;“此外，总干事非常清楚，那个时期的一些广播过去和现在都是如此。 ，不可原谅，完全不可接受，今天永远不会播出。”

;

;布兰德没有回应 PA 通讯社的置评请求。

;

;他被指控强奸， 《泰晤士报》、《星期日泰晤士报》和第 4 频道的《Dispatches》联合调查后，他在 2006 年至 2013 年间遭受了性侵犯和精神虐待，当时他正处于名气巅峰，为 BBC 和第 4 频道工作并主演好莱坞电影。布兰德否认了这些指控。

;

;第四频道已宣布对其主持人在其频道的时间进行调查。它还表示已经删除了所有以 Brand 为特色的内容，而 BBC 则表示已经审查了内容并“经过深思熟虑后决定删除其中一些内容，因为评估结果现在低于公众的预期”。

;
; < p>;;相关：;;拉塞尔·布兰德 (Russell Brand) 如何保持收入和影响力;

;
;

;托管布兰德视频频道的 YouTube 和播放他的 Under The Skin 播客的播客平台 Acast 都表示，他会不通过其网站和应用程序上的广告赚钱。

;

;布兰德两极分化巡演的剩余演出也被推迟，但是，;右翼视频平台 Rumble 表示针对布兰德的指控与其平台“无关”

;

;该视频托管网站还表示，它代表着与 YouTube 不同的“价值观”，并“致力于捍卫自由互联网的重要事业”。

;

;“我们不认为声明还写道：“我们不同意许多《Rumble》创作者的行为，但我们拒绝惩罚他们与我们平台无关的行为。”

;

;布兰德在其平台上发布的最后一个视频否认有任何犯罪行为指控并称他“滥交”，但他的所有关系都是“双方自愿的”。

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 04:52:02 +0800 Haiti’s most powerful gang boss calls for uprising to overthrow prime ministerhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/21/haiti-jimmy-barbecue-cherizier-overthrow-prime-minister-ariel-henry
;;2023-09-21T19:44:01Z;
;
;;一名被蒙面枪手包围的中年男子盯着镜头。
;

;最严重继;海地;最严重的人道主义危机之后，美洲的人道主义危机再次发生戏剧性转变。强大的帮派老大走上街头，呼吁武装起义，推翻该国不受欢迎的总理。

;

;Jimmy Chérizier，;一名绰号为“烧烤”的警察变身黑帮大佬，周二发出武装号召，有报道称美国正在准备请求联合国安理会批准由肯尼亚主导的干预措施，旨在解决加勒比国家不断升级的安全危机。

;
;

;;相关：;;“这是地狱”：治安维持者走上海地街头对帮派进行血腥报复;

;
;

;“我们正在发起一场以任何方式推翻阿里尔·亨利政府的斗争，”谢里齐尔谈到海地总理时说道，这位总理在 2021 年总统若弗内尔·莫伊兹被暗杀后上台。“我们的斗争将这名团伙头目告诉路透社。

;

;自莫伊兹在太子港住所被谋杀以来，海地的动乱不断加剧。从那时起，携带步枪的团伙占领了海地首都 90% 的地区，并且发生了;杀戮、绑架和性暴力的激增;，将城市的大部分地区变成了禁区。数百万人正在为吃饭而苦苦挣扎，部分原因是帮派检查站封锁了食品供应路线。

;

;从相对安全的山坡社区，“你可以看到[下面]的城市在燃烧……你可以看到房屋在燃烧。最近访问该国的国际危机组织海地专家迭戈·达林 (Diego Da Rin) 说：“即使是在白天，你也会看到所有的枪声。”

;

;“去那里真的很困难，而且真的很困难。”离开时，当你在飞机上时，只是想：‘我可以离开——但大多数住在这里的人别无选择，’”Da Rin 补充道。 “[警察]现在完全不敌帮派。”

; ;

;政府未能制止流血事件，导致了;一个名为“Bwa Kale”的治安维持运动;，公民们用砍刀、石块和枪支奋起反抗帮派。

;

;本周，海地主教会议对所谓的“[海地]历史上持续时间最长、最致命的社会政治和安全危机之一”表示遗憾。主教团体警告说：“一场针对和平和手无寸铁的人民的低强度战争正在全国范围内肆虐。”自去年十月以来，陷入困境的亨利政府和外国领导人一直呼吁< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/oct/17/un-security-council-haiti-session">;某种外国干预;来帮助;海地不堪重负的警察部队重新控制了这座日益无法无天的首都。一位美国高级外交官最近告诉《迈阿密先驱报》，美国官员一直在“绕地球一周”寻找愿意参与这一努力的国家，尽管大多数国家由于涉及危险而不愿参与。

; ;

;干预似乎更接近了这一点一周，肯尼亚总统威廉·鲁托;宣布;他的国家将成为“联合国支持的主要国家” ”。

;

;“我们致力于部署一支专业团队来全面评估局势并制定可行的战略，从而实现长期解决方案，”鲁托在与阿里尔·亨利的会面中表示。周三。

;
;

;;相关：;;肯尼亚向海地派遣警察的提议引发了人权担忧;

;
;

;周二，美国总统乔·拜登在联合国大会上表示：“海地人民不能再等太久了。”彭博社援引匿名消息人士的话称，美国最早可以在下周请求联合国安理会批准此次任务。

;

;Da Rin 预计，如果安全部队成员能够在 11 月或 12 月抵达海地，决议通过。 “我们预计会有大约 2,000 名警察，也许还有一些军事后备部队，”他说道，并预测：“规模不会像之前的武装干预那么庞大。”

;

;这支部队的前景对于一个自 19 世纪以来经历过一系列灾难性外国干预的国家来说，入境是一个高度敏感的问题。最近的一次行动是 2004 年至 2017 年联合国维和行动，名为“联海稳定团”(Minustah)，它因引发霍乱疫情、造成数千人死亡、性虐待指控和;太子港最大的棚户区太阳城发生涉嫌大屠杀;。;

; ;

;在海地首都的街道上，有人怀疑是否有另一个人干预将会起作用。许多民间社会成员担心这支部队只会帮助支持亨利，批评者指责亨利破坏了解决海地政治危机和安排对国家至关重要的新选举的努力;没有民选官员;。

;

;“即将到来的 1,000 名肯尼亚人不会64 岁的安全特工 Sonthonax Jules 表示：“我们必须解决我们的安全问题，因为美国至少来过这里三次，安全状况变得更糟。”

;

;“没有任何力量可以解决海地的问题问题。海地的问题只能由海地人来解决。”Jules 补充道。

;

;60 岁的女推销员 Clerina Confie 表示谨慎乐观，认为干预措施可能会改善安全状况，让她能够回到自己在海地的家。

;

;但目前，康菲计划留在太子港市中心的一个废弃剧院，那里是逃离帮派暴力的难民的避难所。 “即使我不得不和孩子们一起睡在街中央，我也不会回到那个地区，”她说。 “如果我一贫如洗，那是因为[帮派]。”

;

;著名人权活动家皮埃尔·埃斯佩兰斯 (Pierre Espérance) 表示，如果不解决治理危机，就无法解决海地的安全危机。< /p>;

;“这些团伙今天如此强大的原因之一是因为国家最高层和警察阶层与土匪勾结，”他说。 “为了改善安全局势，必须领导国家。”

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 04:22:01 +0800 Actor Angus Cloud died of accidental overdose, coroner sayshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/21/actor-angus-cloud-died-of-accidental-overdose-coroner-says
;;2023-09-21T19:33:58Z;
;
;;一张剃光头、留着红胡子的年轻白人的特写照片。
;

;北加州验尸官办公室周四表示，演员安格斯·克劳德 (Angus Cloud) 于 7 月因意外服用过量可卡因、芬太尼和其他物质而死亡。

;

;克劳德的死因是“急性中毒”，原因是“阿拉米达县验尸局表示，这是甲基苯丙胺、可卡因、芬太尼和苯二氮卓类药物的综合影响。办公室证实服药过量纯属意外。

;

;这位演员于 7 月 31 日在奥克兰父母家中被宣布死亡。他当时 25 岁。

;

;来自奥克兰的克劳德因在《幸福感》中饰演毒贩费斯科·“菲斯”·奥尼尔而声名鹊起。他很快就成为了粉丝们的最爱。

;

;对一些人来说，克劳德看起来和菲斯一样自然，以至于他们怀疑他与角色;相同——;演员挑战了这一观念。

;

;“当人们说‘这一定很容易！’时，我确实感到困扰。你可以进去做你自己。我想，“你为什么不去做呢？”事情没那么简单。”;Cloud 告诉 Variety;。 “我为这个角色带来了很多东西。你可以相信你想要的。这与我无关。”

;

;克劳德在出演《幸福感》之前没有演过戏。当他走在纽约的街道上时，选角星探埃莱奥诺·亨德里克斯注意到了他。克劳德一开始很抗拒，怀疑这是一场骗局。随后，选角导演詹妮弗·文迪蒂 (Jennifer Venditti) 会见了他，而剧集主创萨姆·莱文森 (Sam Levinson) 最终让他与赞达亚 (Zendaya) 一起在该剧的前两季中担任联合主演。

;

;在当时的一份声明中在他去世后，他的家人表示，克劳德一直在与父亲的去世作斗争。

;

;“尽管我的儿子对父亲的英年早逝深感悲痛……但他的最后一天是快乐的，”丽莎·克劳德·麦克劳克林 (Lisa Cloud McLaughlin)他的母亲在儿子去世后不久在一份声明中说道。 “他谈到他打算帮助供养他上大学的姐妹，并在情感和经济上帮助他的妈妈。他并不打算结束自己的生命。

;

;“当我们拥抱晚安时，我们说我们多么相爱，他说他早上会见到我。”

;

;康纳克劳德的父亲希基于 5 月 18 日死于;间皮瘤;，这是一种通常由接触石棉引起的癌症。

;

;这位演员“因失去希基而痛苦不已”，希基的家人于七月在他的祖国爱尔兰为他举行了葬礼。在他最后的社交媒体帖子之一中，Angus Cloud 在 ;Instagram;，标题为：“想念你兄弟”。

;

;“我们唯一的安慰是知道安格斯现在与他最好的朋友父亲团聚。安格斯对他与心理健康的斗争持开放态度，我们希望他的去世能够提醒其他人，他们并不孤单，不应该独自默默地与之抗争，”根据家人的声明。

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 03:52:01 +0800 Bolsonaro met with army, navy and air force heads to discuss coup – reportshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/21/bolsonaro-military-coup-plans-former-secretary-reports
;;2023-09-21T18:51:12Z;
;
;;9 月 15 日，Jair Bolsnonaro 在巴西圣保罗向支持者致意。
;

;;贾尔·博尔索纳罗;的前秘书<据报道，他告诉调查人员，他的前老板去年年底会见了巴西陆军、海军和空军负责人，讨论军事政变的“政变计划”。

;

;这些说法 –巴西两家最重要的新闻媒体 O Globo 和 UOL 对此进行了报道，促使人们呼吁将涉嫌右翼阴谋者绳之以法。

;

;博尔索纳罗，前陆军上尉，对 1964-85 年巴西军队表示钦佩2018 年，在反建制选民的愤怒爆发中，独裁政权以民主方式赢得了权力。但批评人士怀疑，在去年 10 月未能赢得连任后，这位 68 岁的民粹主义者开始考虑保留权力的其他形式。

;

;新闻网站 UOL ;报道; 博尔索纳罗的前副官毛罗·西德中校告诉联邦警察，在博尔索纳罗在选举中输给左翼竞争对手路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦后，他向博尔索纳罗提出了一项此类计划。

;

;据报道，前外交政策顾问菲利佩·马丁斯向博尔索纳罗展示了这份文件草案，据称概述了举行新选举和逮捕政治对手的计划。据报道，马丁斯和博尔索纳罗于 2022 年 12 月 18 日举行了一次“秘密会议”。

;

;Cid 在 5 月份被捕后与警方达成了认罪协议，据报道，他告诉调查人员，博尔索纳罗随后在一次会议上提出了该计划与军事高层。据 O Globo 和 UOL 报道，博尔索纳罗的前助手告诉警方，当时的海军司令阿尔米尔·卡尼尔海军上将表示支持这一“政变计划”。然而，陆军最高指挥部负责人拒绝了这个想法。

;

;巴西电视网 CNN 也报道了;这些指控;，西德告诉调查人员，海军指挥官告诉博尔索纳罗“他的部队已经准备好采取行动，只是在等待他的命令”。

;

;博尔索纳罗尚未对周四的具体指控做出回应，但此前否认策划政变。在最近的一次采访中，这位前总统似乎暗示他可能已经提出了这样的想法。

;

;“我可以讨论任何事情，我可以思考任何事情，但只要我不提出来付诸实践是没有问题的。”博尔索纳罗 ;告诉;一位来自 O Globo 的政治专栏作家。据报道，博尔索纳罗补充道：“一个人可以说，‘让我们抢劫中央银行’。” “他们不能做的就是将其付诸实践。”

;

;博尔索纳罗领导的自由党 (PL) 主席瓦尔德马·科斯塔·内托 (Valdemar Costa Neto) 告诉 CNN 巴西频道：“博尔索纳罗从未主张政变。”

;

;卡尼尔和马丁斯没有立即发表评论。

;

;“如果这一信息得到证实，那就证明我们自去年以来一直在谴责的事情......政变是巴西左翼社会主义与自由党 (PSOL) 主席朱利亚诺·梅代罗斯 (Juliano Medeiros) 表示：“确实正在计划之中。”

;

;“[博尔索纳罗]失败了，但我毫不怀疑他直接参与了这件事， ”梅代罗斯补充道。如果所谓的政变阴谋成功，“也许我们会在另一个流亡的国家进行这次对话”。

;

;政府国会领袖、参议员兰道夫·罗德里格斯 (Randolfe Rodrigues) 在推特上写道：“司法系统必须是无情的与那些试图摧毁民主法治的政变分子。绝对不能特赦！”

;

;“Jair 是时候做好入狱准备了！”左翼议员吉列尔梅·布洛斯 (Guilherme Boulos) 在推特上回应了他所说的有关巴西前极右翼领导人的“重磅炸弹”报道。

;

;奥古斯托·海莱诺 (Augusto Heleno)，退役陆军将军，也是博尔索纳罗 2019 年执政期间最强硬的成员之一-2023 年政府否认了解任何此类阴谋。 “在博尔索纳罗总统执政期间，这种对话从未进行过。从一开始，他就总是谈论在[宪法]四线内行事，” Heleno ;告诉;新闻网站G1。

;

;卢拉政府的支持者表示，最新的披露增强了他们的信念巴西的民主已经接近灾难，而博尔索纳罗正是这场阴谋的中心。 “我绝对毫不怀疑[博尔索纳罗参与其中]，”梅代罗斯说。

;
;;木星的卫星木卫二
;

;木星众多卫星之一的木卫二广阔的地下海洋包含科学家发现，碳是生命的关键成分之一。

;

;詹姆斯·韦伯太空望远镜的观测表明，月球表面的二氧化碳冰源自位于 10 度以下的咸海洋。一英里厚的冰壳。尽管这些发现并没有回答外星生命是否潜伏在寒冷、阴暗的深处的问题，但它们增强了这样一种观点，即木卫二的海洋可能是太阳系中最有希望寻找它的地方。

;

;“这是一件大事，我对此感到非常兴奋，”美国德克萨斯州西南研究所的地球化学家兼合著者 Christopher Glein 博士说。 ;“;我们还不知道欧罗巴海洋中是否真的存在生命。但这一新发现为木卫二的海洋是存在现存生命的良好选择提供了证据。从天体生物学的角度来看，这种环境看起来很诱人。”

;

;木卫二宽 2,000 英里，比月球略小。假设的生命形式必须应对一些极端的逆境，包括很少超过-140°C的表面温度和来自木星的辐射。但是，木卫二的海洋——深 40-100 英里（64-160 公里），位于其冰面以下 10 至 15 英里——使木卫二成为寻找生命的主要竞争者。深海的潜在宜居性取决于其化学成分，包括碳等生物必需元素的丰度。

;

;之前的研究已确定欧罗巴表面存在固体 CO;2; 冰，但尚不清楚这些物质是由地下海洋喷出的还是由陨石撞击传递到月球表面的。最新的观测利用詹姆斯·韦伯望远镜的近红外观测绘制了木卫二表面 CO;2; 的分布图。这显示了塔拉地区 (Tara Regio) 的 CO;2; 热点，这是一个面积约 695 平方英里（1,800 平方公里）的所谓“混沌地形”区域。这里的表面主要是冰川裂缝和冰脊，这些冰脊是通过地质过程迫使冰块浮出表面而形成的。

;

;“在欧罗巴冰壳富含盐分的区域中发现二氧化碳表明美国宇航局喷气推进实验室的天体生物学家兼合著者凯文·汉德 (Kevin Hand) 表示，CO;2; 来自下方的海洋，而不是来自外部来源，例如撞击木卫二的陨石和离子。; Hand 将这一发现描述为“至关重要”。 “据我们所知，生命喜欢吃和呼吸二氧化碳，因此木卫二海洋可能含有丰富的 CO;2; 的迹象对于该海洋的宜居性和任何潜在的居民来说是一个很好的预兆。 ”

;

;天体生物学家经常提到地球生命中存在的“六大”元素：碳、氢、氧、氮、磷和硫。其中四种元素——碳、氢、氧和硫——现已在木卫二上被发现，尽管目前还不清楚硫是从海洋到达地表还是来自木星的另一颗卫星木卫一。

;

;“木卫二海洋中碳的可用性支持了木卫二海洋的宜居性，”格莱因说。 “JWST 和将于明年发射的木卫二快艇任务的未来观测应该为我们提供进一步的线索，以了解木卫二上是否容易存在其他生命组成部分，例如氮。”

;

;研究结果发表在《科学》杂志上，同时还进行了第二次分析，该分析还分析了木卫二上碳同位素（不同形式的元素）的比率。高碳 12 与碳 13 的比率可能是生命过程的一个指标，但在这种情况下，分析证明并没有结论。

;

;安德鲁·科茨教授，伦敦大学学院 Mullard 空间科学实验室行星科学主任没有参与这项工作的他表示，这些发现“重要且有趣”。 “For life, you need liquid water, the right chemistry, a source of energy and enough time for life to develop,” he added. “We think all of those may be present on Europa.”

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 02:52:01 +0800 Mexican cartels are fifth-largest employers in the country, study findshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/21/mexico-cartels-fifth-largest-employer-study
;;2023-09-21T18:21:03Z;
;
;;A Sinaloa cartel member prepares methamphetamine capsules in a safe house in Mexico.
;

;Organised crime groups in Mexico have about 175,000 members – making them the fifth-biggest employer in the country, according to new research published in the journal Science.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Son of Joaquin 'El Chapo' Guzman extradited to the US for drug trafficking;

;
;

;Using a decade of data on homicides, missing persons and incarcerations, as well as information about interactions between rival factions, the paper published on Thursday mathematically modeled overall cartel membership, and how levels of violence would respond to a range of policies.

;

;The authors argue that the best way to reduce the bloodshed would be to cut cartel recruitment – whereas locking up more members would actually increase the murder rate.

;

;“More than 1.7 million people in Latin America are incarcerated, and adding more people to saturated jails will not solve the insecurity problem,” wrote the authors.

;

;The number of homicides in Mexico more than tripled between 2007 and 2021 – when the government reported 34,000 victims, or nearly 27 victims for every 100,000 inhabitants – making it one of the deadliest countries in Latin America.

;

;At a national level, ;two organised crime groups – the Sinaloa cartel and the Jalisco New Generation cartel – battle for domination;. But analysts have identified ;198 armed groups; in Mexico, many of which are subcontractors to bigger players but also undertake local turf disputes.

;

;The paper, titled Reducing cartel recruitment is the only way to lower violence in Mexico, was cautiously welcomed by security analysts in the field. “It is a first of its kind,” said Victoria Dittmar, a researcher for the Insight Crime thinktank, who did not take part in the study. “I haven't seen any other estimates of how many people we believe are somehow related to criminal groups.”

;

;But Dittmar said the figure would depend on the definition of a cartel and what constitutes membership, since working for a crime faction is very different to being formally employed.

;

;“It can be very difficult to say who is a member of a criminal organisation, and who isn't,” said Dittmar. “What about a politician that receives money? Or someone who cooperates with the group just once?”

;

;The idea of targeting cartel recruitment to reduce violence is itself not new, said Valentin Pereda, a professor at the University of Montreal who also was not involved in the study.

;
;

;;Related: ;;As Mexico's epidemic of violence rages on, authorities seem powerless to stop it;

;
;

;“If cartels cannot recruit, then they cannot replace their losses, then they cannot keep fighting each other,” said Pereda. “It makes sense. But until now no one had provided a data-based assessment of how it would work in practice.”

;

;But it is one thing to say recruitment should be reduced, and another to come up with policies to make that happen.

;

;Not every member of an organised crime group is involved in violent activities, which means specific subgroups must be targeted separately.

;

;These include the typical profile of the young, working-class man who might be recruited as a ;sicario ;– or gunman – or to enforce territorial control. But they also include ;highly trained deserters from the Mexican police and the militaries across Latin America;.

;

;Pereda added that reducing recruitment is also far from the only way to reduce violence, arguing that disarming the cartels must be a central part of any strategy.

;

;“One thing that is missing from this study is that violence in Mexico is also a product of the weaponry that is used,” said Pereda. “We're not talking about people with knives going at each other in a bar. We're talking about paramilitary units with military-grade weapons.”

;

;The paper enters a debate across Latin America as to how best to reduce violence, encapsulated by two starkly different approaches in Mexico and El Salvador.

;

;;Mexico's president Andrés Manuel Lopéz Obrador's “hugs, not bullets” policy; makes a similar case to that of the new paper: that by offering economic alternatives to young people, they would be less tempted to join cartels, and violence would fall.

; ;

;As implemented, however, the strategy has failed to reduce overall violence, which has ;increased during this administration;.

;

;In El Salvador, meanwhile, President Nayib Bukele has drastically reduced violence by doing precisely the opposite of what the paper prescribes: around ;2% of the country's population; has been jailed in a mass incarceration spree that has prompted accusations of ;systematic human rights violations;.

;
;

;;Related: ;;El Salvador crackdown breaks the gangs – at huge cost to human rights;

;
;

;“The logic behind Bukele's strategy is not to incarcerate all gang members, but to use those who are incarcerated as hostages and make their safety behind bars conditional to the behaviour of their associates who are not imprisoned,” said Pereda.

;

;Pereda doubts such a strategy would work in Mexico, where it would imply an even more draconian policy of incarceration – and human rights abuses.

;

;“But the experience of El Salvador shows that organised crime groups are political entities – and that you can devise ways to manipulate their behaviour by treating them as such.”

;The careers of two of ;Norway;'s most powerful female politicians are hanging in the balance after their husbands were found to be secretly trading in shares.

;

;In two separate cases, the country's foreign minister, Anniken Huitfeldt, of the Labour party, and the Conservative party leader and ;former prime minister Erna Solberg;, are facing calls to resign. They both deny having knowledge of what their husbands were doing.

;Among those calling for resignations was Rasmus Hansson, a Green party politician, who said the two women were damaging the reputation of Norwegian politics. “Walk now. Please,” he wrote on Facebook, adding that if they refused to go their parties should remove them.

;

;On Thursday, she said she was willing to continue as party leader but that she would leave the decision to her party.

;

;

;

;“We like to think we have a high degree of gender equality in Norway. But this is a kind of sexism.”

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 00:52:01 +0800 Swedish government faces backlash after slashing climate budgethttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/21/swedish-government-faces-backlash-after-slashing-climate-budget
;;2023-09-21T16:21:45Z;
;
;;Elisabeth Svantesson
;

;The Swedish government is facing a huge backlash – including threats of no-confidence votes against its climate minister – after slashing the country's climate budget while admitting that it will dramatically increase carbon dioxide emissions.

;

;The minority-run coalition, which has been in power for just under a year, announced on Wednesday it would be cutting funding for climate and environmental measures next year by 259m krona (£19m) and introducing tax cuts on petrol and diesel.

;

;While long-term emissions are expected to decrease by 2045, the government is now expected to miss its 2030 transport targets.

;

;By its own estimates, emissions will increase by 5.9m-9.8m tonnes of CO;2; equivalents by 2030 as a consequence of government decisions made between 1 July 2022 and 1 July 2023.

;

;The move has drawn comparisons to the UK, where Rishi Sunak this week also attracted condemnation after performing a significant U-turn on Britain's climate commitments by ;pushing back the deadline for selling new petrol and diesel cars; and the phasing out of gas boilers.

;

;Since Elisabeth Svantesson, the Swedish finance minister, made the announcement, the government has faced heavy criticism from other parties – including from those within the ruling coalition, sources have told the Guardian.

;

;Some commentators have suggested it could pull apart prime minister Ulf Kristersson's coalition between his own party, the Moderates, Christian Democrats and Liberals, dependent on the support of the far-right Sweden Democrats. But a government source rebutted such claims, saying the coalition was “cooperating very well”.

;

;Rickard Nordin, climate and energy spokesperson for the opposition Centre party, condemned the climate cuts, which he said were unprecedented.

;

;Along with other parties, he said, he would do what it took to stop the budget and presented the government with an ultimatum. He said if it did not deliver a climate action plan before Christmas, they would issue the Liberal climate and energy minister, Romina Pourmokhtari, with a motion of no confidence.

;

;“What has happened is that the Swedish government is consciously increasing emissions,” he said. “No Swedish government in modern times has consciously increased emissions. Few countries in the world have done that and it's extremely serious.”

;

;Swedish climate law required the government to reduce emissions, he said, and he planned to hold Kristersson's government accountable.

;

;Nordin said: “We are going to start by putting forward alternative proposals and use every tool we have in parliament to stop this.”

;

;He accused the government of underestimating public and political strength of feeling on climate. “They have underestimated the explosive power in this, because in Sweden we have a united business community and citizens are screaming out for leadership on climate politics while the government is doing the opposite.”

;

;Many blame the influence of the Sweden Democrats, which has members who have denied the climate crisis, for the Moderates' shift in priorities.

;

;“When you sell your soul to a populist and nationalist party with plenty of climate deniers, this is the result,” said Nordin.

;

;Mats Engström, senior policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations, said: “It's clear it will be very difficult for Sweden to reach its climate targets. This is a national explosion of the tension since this government was founded.

;

;“This must be really hard for the Liberals and Romina Pourmokhtari. But she is not the party leader – and for the party there may be other issues that are more important, like the school system.”

;

;Pourmokhtari has so far stood behind the budget, telling Green party spokesperson Per Bolund in a debate on SVT that it was the “third largest budget ever for climate and environment” and would help Sweden reach its 2045 climate goals.

;

;Engström said the developments in the UK and Sweden were part of a Europe-wide pattern. He said: “You have leaders and parties who are now criticising the previous climate policy for their elections and standing. This rhetoric and what Sunak said reflects what's happening in Sweden.

;

;“I know there are concerns in other European capitals about whether Sweden will stay a climate leader. I wouldn't say it will totally destroy this reputation but it will fuel concerns in other parts of Europe that Sweden is changing its mind.”

;

;As well as affecting Sweden's international standing as a climate leader, which Engström said was already raising concerns in European capitals, it also has strong potential consequences on domestic attitudes.

;

;Maria Xylia, a senior research fellow at Stockholm Environment Institute, said In Sweden the image of environmental leadership was for many a question of national identity.

;

;She said the government's decision to scrap ;stadsmiljöavtal ;;(;the urban environment agreement providing sustainability support to muncipalities and regional authorities) was also a big problem.

;

;While the government has pledged to replace it, she fears it will create a vacuum of resources in the meantime by creating uncertainty. “We have some very critical years coming up to 2030,” she said.

;

;;Fridays For Future;, the youth climate movement started by Swedish activist Greta Thunberg, said the budget was “a catastrophe” and “a big betrayal”, inviting people to join Friday's national climate strike in protest.

;

;Linna Gadde, a Fridays for Future spokesperson, said there was a lot of anger about the budget. She said: “The government is not meeting the situation as seriously as they should because we're in an emergency. The budgets before have been bad but this one is even worse.”

;

;The group is marking the end of its week of action on Friday, with a strike and protest march in central Stockholm. Gadde said Fridays for Future was expecting thousands to attend, and she expected the budget announcement to bring more people out.

;

;“We need to use our right to demonstrate to stand up for what's right and show that people have the power.”
